phrasal verbs.meaning: the state of being a prisoner in your own house rather than in a prison
phrasal verbs.example: She was placed under house arrest.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to start focusing on your work/study. (Inseparable)
phrasal verbs.example: I work as a teacher and we've got exams coming soon, so we all need to knuckle down. I study law, and I have exams soon, so I need to knuckle down.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to do something you have intended to do, but not had time. (Inseparable)
phrasal verbs.example: Can you cook? I would love learn how to cook, but I just haven't got round to it. I've been too busy. Can you paint? I like painting, but I cannot do it very well. I've just never got round to taking classes.
Their accountant was charged with cooking the books, and now he's in jail.
I have a big exam tomorrow, so I'll be burning the midnight oil to review all the material.

idioms.meaning: to initiate conversation in a social setting
idioms.example: He told a joke to break the ice at the party.

idioms.word: Hit the nail on the head
idioms.meaning: to describe exactly what is causing a situation or problem
idioms.example: You hit the nail on the head when you said the problem was poor communication.

topic vocab.meaning: able to be maintained at a certain rate or level
topic vocab.example: The company is committed to sustainable business practices.

topic vocab.meaning: the action or process of innovating
topic vocab.example: The tech industry thrives on constant innovation.

grammar.meaning: a verb tense that expresses actions completed at an unspecified time

grammar.example: If I were rich, I would travel the world.

phrases, collocations.meaning: to move forward or advance toward a goal
phrases, collocations.example: We need to make progress on this project by Friday.
The manager took responsibility for the team's mistakes.
